fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64714].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Importing issues using CSV returns error when username contains space

h3. Environment
* JIRA Cloud version {{7.1.0-OD-04-012}} 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a user with a space in their username (e.g: john doe)
# Select *Import Issues from CSV* from *Issues* blue menu bar.
# Upload *CSV Source File*. Click _Next_.
# Select any project. Click _Next_.
# Map appropriate fields and click _Next_.
# Click _Validate_

h3. Expected Results
No error is retured.

h3. Actual Results
Error is returned:
{noformat}
The validation process has found 1 error/s:

Issue can't be created due to the error/s [ The reporter specified is not a user. ]
{noformat}

or
{noformat}
The validation process has found 1 error/s:

Issue can't be created due to the error/s [ User 'johndoe' does not exist. ]
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
* Trying to escape the space with {{' '}} or {{" "}} or {{/ /}} doesn't work as well.

* The documentation on *Importing Issues* also does not specify whether this is allowed or not:
** https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiracloud/importing-issues-737772291.html

h3.Workaround
* Remove the space in the username
fields.summary: Importing issues using CSV returns error when username contains space
Rapid board ordering seems not to match Pivotal ordering
Analytics - track when import was finished from onboarding page
The information displayed in the CSV import log is not correct

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64703].
  {panel}

If you export a currency field from Excel to CSV you will get a record with a text like:
{code} 
" 5,790.14 "
"$ 5,790.14 "
"5,790.14 USD"
" (3,283.78)"
"56.71%"
" .2,431.70 ", 
(45.00) 
{code}

All the values presented above are not recognized as number even if they should.

The algorithm for converting them to numbers is not so complex, it requires removal of all characters that are not digits, decimal-dot (configurable), percent or (). If () are present the number will be negative and you can remove them. If percent is present you will remove it and divide the recognized number by 100. "10%" is always considered to be "0.1" float.

The idea is to call atof() only on something that was sanitized first.
fields.summary: CSV Import does fail to recognize different number formats including currency ones

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64702].
  {panel}

Epic Links are not imported if the Epic issues are located after the issues with epic links from inside the import file

WARN - Cannot add value [ Epic: Billing ] to CustomField Epic Link in Issue null. Probably value was in incorrect format

This means that now the only way to successfully import the data is to be sure that all Epics are listed before the other type of issues. 

Still this makes quite hard to prepare the JSON file. Think that in our case we are getting 15.000 issues.
fields.summary: Epic Links are not imported if the Epic issues are located after the issues with epic links from inside the import file

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64701].
  {panel}

It seems that an originalEstimate value of 11 hours ( "PT11H" ) is converted into "1d 4h" in JIRA instead of "1d 3h".

Any idea why this happens? JIRA is configured using the default 8 hours / day, 5 days a week.
Quote: Your current conversion rates are 1w = 5d and 1d = 8h.

Strange but this seems like a bug related to time-zone, as it happens that the server is using UTC locally and the client is using BST (GMT+1). Anyway, duration should have nothing to do with time-zone.
fields.summary: JIM JSON import of originalEstimate is doing unexpected round-up
Check for creating a user named Unassigned or unassigned

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64697].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When the application context of a custom field is set to some specific project, the custom field will not appear in the mapping select list when doing a CSV import with issues of multiple projects.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a custom field with the name "TestCF".
# Configure the custom field by changing its application context from "Global context" to a specific project.
# Launch a CSV import by setting "Import to Project" to "Derfined in CSV" (see screenshot below)
 !2016-11-14_csv-config.png|thumbnail! 
# On the next page try to select the custom field "TestCF" from the mapping dropdown list.

h3. Expected Results
"TestCF" appears in the dropdown list

h3. Actual Results
"TestCF" missing in the dropdown list unless we change the "Import to Project" setting to the project which the context of custom field is defined to.
 
h3.Workaround
Temporarily change the context of custom field to "Global context" when doing the CSV import, and revert the change after the import is done.
fields.summary: Custom field without Global context does not appear in the map list when importing CSV file with multiple projects

I tried importing the following JSON. The "items" member of the first history element is an object rather than the expected array. 

{code}

            "name": "Kanban Sample",
            "key": "KBS",
            "description": "Kanban Sample",
            "workflowSchemeName": "GreenHopper Workflow Scheme",
            "issues": [

                        {
                            "created": "P3D",
                            "items": {
                                "fieldType": "jira",
                                "field": "status",
                                "from": "1",
                                "fromString": "Open",
                                "to": "10001",
                                "toString": "Selected for Development"
                            }
                        },
                        {
                            "created": "P2D",
                            "items": {
                                "fieldType": "jira",
                                "field": "status",
                                "from": "10001",
                                "fromString": "Selected for Development",
                                "to": "10004",
                                "toString": "In Development"
                            }
                        },
                        {
                            "created": "P1D",
                            "items": {
                                "fieldType": "jira",
                                "field": "status",
                                "from": "10004",
                                "fromString": "In Development",
                                "to": "6",
                                "toString": "Closed"
                            }
                        }
                    ],
                    "summary": "Instructions for deleting this sample board and project are in the description for this card",
                    "issueType": "Story",
                    "status": "Closed",
                    "description": "*To Delete the Sample Project (Must be performed by a user with Administration rights)* \n- Open the administration interface by clicking \"Administration\" at the top right \n- Under the Projects section, click \"All Projects\" \n- Select the \"Delete\" link for this project\n\n*To Delete this Rapid Board (Must be performed by the owner of this Rapid Board or an Administrator)*\n- Click the Cog at the top right of this board\n- Select \"Delete\"",
                    "priority": "Major",
                    "created": "P7D",
                    "comments": [

                            "body": "Created 7 days ago"
                        },
                        {
                            "body": "Open to Selected for Development 3 days ago\r\nSelected for Development to In Development 2 days ago\r\nIn Development to Closed 1 days ago"
                        }
                    ]
                }
            ]
        }
    ]
}
{code}

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64692].
  {panel}

Copied from https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-32034

While importing a CSV file into existing project (defined in CSV), user gets the error message attached, as follows:
{panel:bgColor=#FFCCFF|borderStyle=none}
Invalid project key TP: Project key or name is already used. If you want to import to an existing project the name and the key must match it exactly.
{panel}
What happens in this case is that the project name and key are case sensitive, which means that the second part of the message is accurate ("project the name and the key must match it exactly"), but the first part of this error message is quite confusing, stating that there's an invalid project key, and also that the project name or key are already in use. That does not make sense.

Steps to replicate:
# Create a project named *Test Project*
# Create CSV file such as 
{noformat}
Project Name,Project Key,Summary
TEST PROJECT,TP,testing CSV
{noformat}
(!) Note that the project name in capital letters is intentional
# In JIRA, choose CSV File import, choose the CSV created in step 2, click next
# Select *Defined in CSV* for _Import to JIRA Project_ option, click next
# Map the fields accordingly, click next
# The error is displayed.
fields.summary: User gets an unclear error message while importing CSV file into existing project

When importing our Pivotal Tracker projects into JIRA on *.atlassian.net, a changed status name caused subsequent imports to fail.

ImportingSteps to reproduce:
# Import a project from Pivotal Tracker
# Determine that the status "IceBox" is silly and change it to "Icebox" within one of your workflows
# Import a second project from Pivotal Tracker
# Import will fail (see error log below, although it is slightly different than the first time that actually mentioned the status name it failed on 'IceBox'.)
# Change the name back to "IceBox"
# Import will succeed

Speculation: Capitalization matters and will jam up an import if different?

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64682].
  {panel}

JDOG in German - JIM has not German translations.  

This is odd because JIM is bundled which means that it's message files were supplied to NZTC for translation.

Looking in TAC you also see translations - https://translations.atlassian.com/dashboard/translate?lang=de_DE#/11/4111/0/ALL/ALL/jira-importer-plugin

However they are not appearing on the JIM pages....

The same can be repeated on BTF instance.

In JIM project there are translation files that are incomplete.
I believe that JIRA is loading TAC and than loading those files from JIM.
Because those local files are incomplete it overrides some translations with default (English) ones.

It may be that removing all translations from JIM project will help (except English of course)
fields.summary: Problem with translations in JIM

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64681].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When importing issues through a CSV file, if there is a semicolon (\;) on the attachment name, the import will fail with the following error: *Cannot parse FILEINFO as attachment info: too many tokens*. This fails even if you quote the file name as in "file;name.jpg", it will still fail.

h3. Expected Results

The import concludes normally.

h3. Actual Results
The error bellow is displayed on the conclusion screen for the import process:
{noformat}
Cannot parse 'ATTACHMENT INFO' as attachment info: too many tokens
{noformat}
 
h3.Workaround
Remove the semicolon from the attachment name.
fields.summary: Cannot import with semicolon on attachment name

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64679].
  {panel}

The returns within an Excel cell are not kept. Users request many imports so it is very hard to manually go through every ticket and insert line breaks. We would want the importer to preserve line breaks for example:
Description
1. First read this line

Perform task A
Perform task B

But, after the .csv file is imported all characters are on one string:
Description
1. First read this linePerform task APerform task B
fields.summary: CSV import does keep original formatting

h4. Description
CSV Import Configuration file does not save the option to automatically checks "Map Field Value". 

h4. Steps to Reproduce
# Select Issues -> Import issues from CSV (does not select a configuration file at this point)
# Check the "Map Field Value" for some fields
# Perform the import and then click on "Save the configuration file"
# Try to perform the import using the configuration file previously generated and confirm that  the checkbox "Map Field Value" is not automatically checked.

h4. Expected results
"Map Field Value" would be automatically marked when using a previously selected configuration file.
fields.summary: "Map field value" option is not saved to CSV Import configuration file

  {panel}

h3. Summary
When trying to import attachment with (chinese/korean/japanese) character in it using JSON importer, issue get created with no attachment.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Import the attached JSON file using the JSON external importer.
# Sample JSON code:
{noformat}
{
  "projects": [
    {
      "key": "MO",
      "name": null,
      "description": "",
      "issues": [
        {
          "priority": "P4 (No Impact/Notify)",
          "description": "ABC ABC",
          "status": "Done",
          "reporter": "user1",
          "issueType": null,
          "resolution": "Fixed",
          "created": "2013-01-03T22:36:00",
          "updated": "2013-01-03T22:36:00",
          "resolutionDate": "2013-01-17T08:22:00",
          "summary": "ABC ABC",
          "assignee": "user1",
          "watchers": [],
          
          "attachments": [
            
            {
              "name": "QC공정(4M기준)_양1.png",
              "attacher": "user1",
              "created": "2015-09-08T09:51:12.1681238+08:00",
              "uri": "file:///C:/Users/IT/Downloads/QC공정(4M기준)_양1.png",
              "description": null
            }
          ],
          "comments": [
                      ]
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
Issue get created together with attachment.

h3. Actual Results

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64672].
  {panel}

h3. Steps to reproduce

# Create a test CSV file with values like "ç", "ã", "á", "ê".
# In the CSV import page from JIRA, choose this file to import.

h3. Current behaviour

# If you keep the default collation (UTF-8), the characters will be handled as "??", like:
#- Refeição - "Refei??o"
#- Salários - "Sal?rios"
# If you change the collation to latin characters (ISO-8859-1), the characters will disappear, as:
#- Refeição - "Refeio"
#- Salários - "Salrios"

h3. Expected behaviour

Import the characters correctly in any of the collations.
fields.summary: CSV import doesn't handle latin characters in any collation
Remove no longer necessary warning from Mantis Setup page
Provide a way for customers to give a feedback from the importers
import from csv - truncated seconds

  {panel}

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64656].
  {panel}

It's great that the newer versions of JIM can create the required mappings, field values, and so on. However, this poses a problem when the user is importing a project on a production system and is not looking carefully at the data.

For example, assume that I've prepared a configuration file that corresponds to a particular type of CSV template. I've tested and verified that the mapping works.

Later, I get a new CSV file from a user that conforms to my previously-generated template, but it contains an incorrect value for one of the field values (say, an incorrect Resolution value). When I go to process the CSV file with JIM, it will go ahead and happily create a new Resolution (which applies to the entire JIRA instance), even if this resolution was just a typo that was meant to be another real resolution. This happens silently, which can lead to other non-localized problems (such as users entering the incorrect resolution values in entirely unrelated projects).

Before beginning the final import process, JIM should warn the user that it is about to create field value 'xxx' for custom field 'yyy', which would eliminate this problem.
fields.summary: JIM needs to warn users before creating new field values

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64655].
  {panel}

Any data exported by JSON Exporter does not include Security Level informations. This means that all imported data by JSON has Security Level set to 'None'. This issue also concerns importing - user cannot specify Security informations

Steps to reproduce:

1. Make sure you have a project with defined Security Levels (e.g. 'None' and 'abc-staff').
2. Create Issue A which is only visible for abc-staff
3. Create Issue B which is visible for everyone
4. Add comment to Issue B which will be visible only for abc-staff
5. List Both issues on Search screen
6. Export Issues to JSON (make sure that user who performs the export has abc-staff permissions)
7. Import exported data in step 6. to other project / other JIRA instance

Expected Version 1: Imported data in step 7. has the same security Levels that had the source issues.
Expected Version 2: Exproted data in step 6. has skipped secured Informations so they are not imported in step 7.

Actual: There is none Security-Level informations is JSON, Step 6. exports all data that is visible for the user who performs the export. Step 7. imports all data with Security Level 'None'.
fields.summary: JSON Export to include Security Informations

>>>> bugzilla <<<<
attachment 1699 created (attachment 1699 [details])
comment for the attachment

usual bug report text
>>>> bugzilla <<<<

>>>> jira <<<<
usual bug report text
>>>> jira <<<<

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64638].
  {panel}

*Problem*:
Customer is migrating from Fogbugz On Demand to JIRA Cloud on a per project basis. The Fogbugz import for JIRA Server allows the mapping of fields that aren't available in the JIRA Cloud Fogbugz import tool.

Below you'll find the customers thorough walk through of the differences between the two import tool environments/mappings. 

{quote}
All screenshots have the Jira cloud importing Fogbugz OnDemand on the left and Jira server import Fogbugz SqlServer database on the right.

*Screen 1 - Projects*
This shows that both support individual project importing. However, you will see that server has one extra step as highlighted by the red underlines.

*Screen 2 - Custom Fields*
This shows the custom fields screen that server has. I do not care about this feature and have no need for it to be available for OnDemand import.

*Screen 3 - Fields*
This shows that the server adds three options for mapping imports that are not available with OnDemand. sFullName is the must have for us.

sCateogry and sPriority would be very nice to have, but I can deal with not having them.

*Screen 4 - Values*
This shows the ui for choosing what the mappings are. Once very nice thing with this is that the configuration file in the earlier steps remembers the mappings I created. So if I run through this for one of our projects we can use mostly the same configuration file for other projects. Also, since the configuration file is text I can write a script to do the user name mapping rather than having to fill in 400+ username ids :).

*Screen 5 - Links*
This shows that the server adds two more link import options. The critical one for us is the duplicate case mapping. See also is nice but we don't actually intentionally use that much.
{quote}
fields.summary: Fogbugz import tool for JIRA Cloud instance needs to mirror JIRA Server Fogbugz import tool

h3. Problem Definition
Currently it is not possible to import issue security level using CSV import

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide feature to import security level for JIRA issue using CSV import

h3. Why this is important
Security is always a biggest concern for any system which this feature when we import issue via CSV import, the imported issues does not have the security level which was set earlier hence we will need to manually bulk edit issues to change the security level after the issue is imported.


h3. Workaround
Perform Bulk edit to change the security level of the issue that has been imported using CSV import
fields.summary: Ability To Import Security Level Using CSV Import

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64635].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
When importing from an external system such as Bitbucket, basically the importer is able to map usernames to JIRA usernames correctly, and create new JIRA accounts when there is no username match in JIRA. However, sometimes usernames from the external system don't match usernames of the same users in JIRA, or on the other hand, usernames in the external system coincidentally match usernames of entirely different users in JIRA (disastrous), and there is no simple way to choose to map with other attributes.

This would probably apply to all External System Import. However, the context in the support case that led to this is Bitbucket to JIRA import. More details in the internal comment.

h3. Suggested Solution
Perform the by-username/by-whatever-it-is-the-importer-uses mapping, as it is being done now, but before the importer moves on to the next stage, allow the user to review and change the mappings manually (while validating consistency of user input, of course - no double mapping), then write the changes to the target directory.
fields.summary: Implement a more configurable mapping between users from External system to JIRA users when importing with JIM
Prevent the csv importer from unintentionally adding users, issue type etc

  {panel}

When the importer fails to parse JSON, the error message says:

{noformat}
Import completed with 2 errors:
Failed to create data bean
Unexpected failure occurred. Importer will stop immediately. Data maybe in an unstable state
{noformat}

However:
# An end user doesn't know or care what a "data bean" is.
# The data is definitely not in an unstable state because we haven't done anything yet.
# The detailed log has an error message that gives the line number and column of the parsing error.

Suggested improvement:
* Report a more meaningful error and include the location directly in the report.  Example: The JSON import file could not be parsed.  Unexpected character ('T' (code 84)): expected a valid value (number, String, array, object, 'true', 'false' or 'null') at line: 2, column: 2
fields.summary: Error message for JSON parse errors is less helpful than it could be

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64632].
  {panel}

When importing is see a log of these messages:
WARN - Commenter named user@corporate.com not found. Creating issue with currently logged in user
WARN - User named user@corporate.com not found. attaching to issue with currently logged in user

Many old entries made by users which left long ago are incorrectly recorded as the admin users (me). The internal user DB is nearly empty and Jira is using AD. The "not found" users exist in AD, but are disabled.
LDAP user filter is NOT configured to hide disabled users.
"ldap.user.filter": "(&(objectCategory=Person)(sAMAccountName=*))"
When i search for the "not found" users in Jira User Management, i find them as inactive. So they are there.

I believe, this is a bug in the design!
Never should an enry be recorded under a wrong user, a user who was not the author/actor of it. That makes the whole imported project useless, if you cannot rely on its correctness. Please let the importing user decide how and if to record such an entry.
I would rather like to reassign open issues to active users after importing, than manually fixing the issues one by one (if possible at all).

Btw. i dont understand when importing partial historical data, why a user needs to exist. Can Jira not store entries from deleted users and still show their names?

Edit: This might be important:
The server runs with a 10 user license only, because we have less than 10 active users at the moment. The bugzilla importer filled the jira_users group up to its limit (10). I think, it should not add active or inactive users to roles/groups, unless told by the importing user.
fields.summary: Entries from disabled/deleted users are imported as currently loggined in user

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow JIM to achieve this feature so that users can import issues without any problems.
fields.summary: I want JIM to understand ansi_x3.110-1983 and unicode-1-1-utf-7 encodings
CSV Importer Time Estimate should be able to configure other time formats than just seconds
JIRA Importers plugin should have parameters for importing data

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64602].
  {panel}

New users which are created by JIM in OD environment are only granted with JIRA access, access to other applications has to be enabled manually after import.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Prepare OD instance with different license limit for each application (e.g. JIRA 50, Confluence 50, Bamboo unlimited)
2. Import new users by any JIM importer (e.g. 60 users via JSON)

Expected behaviour:
Imported users are granted access to all active applications.
Licnese limit for each application is respected.
Import log indicates which users was granted with application access.

Actual behaviour:
Imported users are only granted access to JIRA application
License limit for JIRA is respected.
fields.summary: New users created by JIM on OD has only JIRA access.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64601].
  {panel}

At the moment, CSV import does not has the ability to auto-format the escape characters specified in the Comments or Description fields. When we use escape characters in the Comment or Description fields, it appears as with the escape characters after the import.

It should support the escape characters like:
- \r (Return)
- \n (Newline)
- \t (Tab)
fields.summary: CSV Importer should has the ability to auto-format the escape characters
Errors parsing dates should count as failures
Add support for longcf plugin that adds additional custom fields to Mantis
When mapping values from CSV files to a select custom field show options that are defined
JIM Should not use ViewStatuses WW action code
Support importing into a custom field with multiple contexts / configuration schemes
Support QA Contact and Alias and any other built-in custom fields in Bugzilla
Do not warn about missing links
External Issue ID should be always re-used if it exists
Allow JSON Importer to update projects
Support mapping custom fields into matching (by type) standard fields (like Computer -> Environment)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64589].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
* In the Map Fields screen of the CSV import wizard, the fields are being shown as localized field names. This can cause confusion because the localized names are ambiguous, i.e. the localization can apply to more than one field.

h3. Suggested Solution
* To have an option for user to be able to show the fields, "Display Field Names in Localized Fashion" or "Display Raw Field Names" or something to that effect.
fields.summary: Fields in Map Fields Screen of CSV Import Wizard is showing localized field name

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64588].
  {panel}

Hi,

it's great for us to use the CSV-Importer for uploading issues including comments with datetime and user information.
After uploading all issues the Activity Stream shows an exact history. When uploading attachments the automatically generated
attachment destroys this history view. (see screenshot).

Kind Regards
Udo Ottink
fields.summary: Option for importing attachments, to disable automatically generated comments

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64587].
  {panel}

We use the CSV importer to regularly import new issues from the bug tracking system of a customer.
With the wizard it was very easy to initially define a mapping between the 2 systems.

The problem is, the CSV importer of Jira can do only INSERT, no UPDATE.
So we have to manually update Jira to keep it in sync with the customers bug tracker.
Our customers do not change very often the issues after we get them, but sometimes they do
and as projects are getting bigger this is becoming too much to handle manually.

Are there any plans to add to the CSV importer the capability to update already imported issues?

Or are there any other solutions to this problem?
Are there any "standard" Jira solutions?

As I see the Jira CSV importer was created as a tool to import data from another system once,
not to keep data in sync between two systems. But with a small extension it could be made into one.
I just could not find this issue anywhere here in Jira's Jira. We need a solution quite urgently.

Regards
Bettina Zucker
fields.summary: Extend JIM to UPDATE already imported issues
